performed_via_github_app.name: Socket Security
performed_via_github_app.description:
### Socket protects your app from malicious dependencies lurking in your open source supply chain.

Open source code makes up 90% of most codebases. It is critical to manage it effectively to reduce your security risk.

## Detect and block open source supply chain attacks

Security teams depend on Socket to prevent malicious open source dependencies from infiltrating their apps.

Socket dramatically improves your open source security posture by _detecting and blocking the attacks you don't expect_ – malware, install scripts, hidden code, typo-squatting, and more – which aren't caught by traditional vulnerability scanners.

- **Block malware** – Block emerging malware threats

- **Block typo-squatting** – Block malicious packages that differ in name by only a few characters, and recommend the correct package

- **Detect hidden code** – Detect obfuscated, minified, or hidden code

- **Detect privileged API usage** – Report when a dependency update introduces new risky API usage – filesystem, network, child_process, eval()

- **Detect suspicious updates** – Sudden inclusion of privileged APIs in patch or minor releases

Socket currently [supports 60 detections](https://socket.dev/npm/issue) in 5 categories: supply chain risk, quality, maintenance, known vulnerabilities, and license problems.

## Take charge of your dependency health

Socket improves security outcomes and reduces work for security teams by **surfacing actionable security information directly inline in GitHub** so developers are empowered to make better decisions.

- **Five minute deployment** – The easiest security product you'll ever deploy in your organization. Just install a GitHub app and you're done.

- **Provide security feedback directly on PRs** – Empower developers to solve security issues before they're deployed into production.

- **Automated security** – Spend security team resources auditing the highest-impact dependencies, instead of all or nothing.

## Socket detects what vulnerability scanners can’t

It's no longer sufficient to scan for known vulnerabilities (CVEs) and stop there. And yet, that's what the leading "supply chain security" products do, leaving you vulnerable.

It can take weeks or months for a CVE to be discovered, reported, and detected by tools. But in today's culture of fast development, a malicious dependency can be updated, merged, and running in production in days or even sometimes hours.

Defenders need a new approach to address emerging threats from malicious dependencies:

- **Maintainer intentionally added malware** – Rogue maintainer sabotaged his own open source package with 100M downloads/month, affecting companies such as Amazon AWS

- **Package hijacked and poisoned w/ cryptominers and password-stealing malware** – Deliberate malware introduced into multiple packages with 30M downloads/month each

- **Package hijacked to add backdoor targeting a specific organization** – Obfuscated malware added to a dependency which targeted a single company, went undetected for over a week, and made it into their production build

- **NPM package manager allowed anyone to publish new versions of any package** – Attackers could publish new versions of any NPM package without authorization _for multiple years_

Using third-party dependencies without proper vetting leaves you open to hacking, breaches, and assorted security misfortune.

performed_via_github_app.description:
### Socket protects your app from malicious dependencies lurking in your open source supply chain.

Open source code makes up 90% of most codebases. It is critical to manage it effectively to reduce your security risk.

## Detect and block open source supply chain attacks

Security teams depend on Socket to prevent malicious open source dependencies from infiltrating their apps.

Socket dramatically improves your open source security posture by _detecting and blocking the attacks you don't expect_ – malware, install scripts, hidden code, typo-squatting, and more – which aren't caught by traditional vulnerability scanners.

- **Block malware** – Block emerging malware threats

- **Block typo-squatting** – Block malicious packages that differ in name by only a few characters, and recommend the correct package

- **Detect hidden code** – Detect obfuscated, minified, or hidden code

- **Detect privileged API usage** – Report when a dependency update introduces new risky API usage – filesystem, network, child_process, eval()

- **Detect suspicious updates** – Sudden inclusion of privileged APIs in patch or minor releases

Socket currently [supports 60 detections](https://socket.dev/npm/issue) in 5 categories: supply chain risk, quality, maintenance, known vulnerabilities, and license problems.

## Take charge of your dependency health

Socket improves security outcomes and reduces work for security teams by **surfacing actionable security information directly inline in GitHub** so developers are empowered to make better decisions.

- **Five minute deployment** – The easiest security product you'll ever deploy in your organization. Just install a GitHub app and you're done.

- **Provide security feedback directly on PRs** – Empower developers to solve security issues before they're deployed into production.

- **Automated security** – Spend security team resources auditing the highest-impact dependencies, instead of all or nothing.

## Socket detects what vulnerability scanners can’t

It's no longer sufficient to scan for known vulnerabilities (CVEs) and stop there. And yet, that's what the leading "supply chain security" products do, leaving you vulnerable.

It can take weeks or months for a CVE to be discovered, reported, and detected by tools. But in today's culture of fast development, a malicious dependency can be updated, merged, and running in production in days or even sometimes hours.

performed_via_github_app.name: Socket Security
performed_via_github_app.description:
### Socket protects your app from malicious dependencies lurking in your open source supply chain.

Open source code makes up 90% of most codebases. It is critical to manage it effectively to reduce your security risk.

## Detect and block open source supply chain attacks

Security teams depend on Socket to prevent malicious open source dependencies from infiltrating their apps.

Socket dramatically improves your open source security posture by _detecting and blocking the attacks you don't expect_ – malware, install scripts, hidden code, typo-squatting, and more – which aren't caught by traditional vulnerability scanners.

- **Block malware** – Block emerging malware threats

- **Block typo-squatting** – Block malicious packages that differ in name by only a few characters, and recommend the correct package

- **Detect hidden code** – Detect obfuscated, minified, or hidden code

- **Detect privileged API usage** – Report when a dependency update introduces new risky API usage – filesystem, network, child_process, eval()

- **Detect suspicious updates** – Sudden inclusion of privileged APIs in patch or minor releases

Socket currently [supports 60 detections](https://socket.dev/npm/issue) in 5 categories: supply chain risk, quality, maintenance, known vulnerabilities, and license problems.

## Take charge of your dependency health

Socket improves security outcomes and reduces work for security teams by **surfacing actionable security information directly inline in GitHub** so developers are empowered to make better decisions.

- **Five minute deployment** – The easiest security product you'll ever deploy in your organization. Just install a GitHub app and you're done.

- **Provide security feedback directly on PRs** – Empower developers to solve security issues before they're deployed into production.

- **Automated security** – Spend security team resources auditing the highest-impact dependencies, instead of all or nothing.

## Socket detects what vulnerability scanners can’t

It's no longer sufficient to scan for known vulnerabilities (CVEs) and stop there. And yet, that's what the leading "supply chain security" products do, leaving you vulnerable.

It can take weeks or months for a CVE to be discovered, reported, and detected by tools. But in today's culture of fast development, a malicious dependency can be updated, merged, and running in production in days or even sometimes hours.

Defenders need a new approach to address emerging threats from malicious dependencies:

- **Maintainer intentionally added malware** – Rogue maintainer sabotaged his own open source package with 100M downloads/month, affecting companies such as Amazon AWS

- **Package hijacked and poisoned w/ cryptominers and password-stealing malware** – Deliberate malware introduced into multiple packages with 30M downloads/month each

- **Package hijacked to add backdoor targeting a specific organization** – Obfuscated malware added to a dependency which targeted a single company, went undetected for over a week, and made it into their production build

- **NPM package manager allowed anyone to publish new versions of any package** – Attackers could publish new versions of any NPM package without authorization _for multiple years_

Using third-party dependencies without proper vetting leaves you open to hacking, breaches, and assorted security misfortune.

What is a CVE?

Contains a high severity Common Vulnerability and Exposure (CVE).

Remove or replace dependencies that include known high severity CVEs. Consumers can use dependency overrides or npm audit fix --force to remove vulnerable dependencies.

Take a deeper look at the dependency

Take a moment to review the security alert above. Review the linked package source code to understand the potential risk. Ensure the package is not malicious before proceeding. If you're unsure how to proceed, reach out to your security team or ask the Socket team for help at support [AT] socket [DOT] dev.

Remove the package

If you happen to install a dependency that Socket reports as Known Malware you should immediately remove it and select a different dependency. For other alert types, you may may wish to investigate alternative packages or consider if there are other ways to mitigate the specific risk posed by the dependency.

Mark a package as acceptable risk

To ignore an alert, reply with a comment starting with @SocketSecurity ignore followed by a space separated list of ecosystem/package-name@version specifiers. e.g. @SocketSecurity ignore npm/foo@1.0.0 or ignore all packages with @SocketSecurity ignore-all

performed_via_github_app.name: Socket Security
performed_via_github_app.description:
### Socket protects your app from malicious dependencies lurking in your open source supply chain.

Open source code makes up 90% of most codebases. It is critical to manage it effectively to reduce your security risk.

## Detect and block open source supply chain attacks

Security teams depend on Socket to prevent malicious open source dependencies from infiltrating their apps.

Socket dramatically improves your open source security posture by _detecting and blocking the attacks you don't expect_ – malware, install scripts, hidden code, typo-squatting, and more – which aren't caught by traditional vulnerability scanners.

- **Block malware** – Block emerging malware threats

- **Block typo-squatting** – Block malicious packages that differ in name by only a few characters, and recommend the correct package

- **Detect hidden code** – Detect obfuscated, minified, or hidden code

- **Detect privileged API usage** – Report when a dependency update introduces new risky API usage – filesystem, network, child_process, eval()

- **Detect suspicious updates** – Sudden inclusion of privileged APIs in patch or minor releases

Socket currently [supports 60 detections](https://socket.dev/npm/issue) in 5 categories: supply chain risk, quality, maintenance, known vulnerabilities, and license problems.

## Take charge of your dependency health

Socket improves security outcomes and reduces work for security teams by **surfacing actionable security information directly inline in GitHub** so developers are empowered to make better decisions.

- **Five minute deployment** – The easiest security product you'll ever deploy in your organization. Just install a GitHub app and you're done.

- **Provide security feedback directly on PRs** – Empower developers to solve security issues before they're deployed into production.

- **Automated security** – Spend security team resources auditing the highest-impact dependencies, instead of all or nothing.

## Socket detects what vulnerability scanners can’t

It's no longer sufficient to scan for known vulnerabilities (CVEs) and stop there. And yet, that's what the leading "supply chain security" products do, leaving you vulnerable.

It can take weeks or months for a CVE to be discovered, reported, and detected by tools. But in today's culture of fast development, a malicious dependency can be updated, merged, and running in production in days or even sometimes hours.

Defenders need a new approach to address emerging threats from malicious dependencies:

- **Maintainer intentionally added malware** – Rogue maintainer sabotaged his own open source package with 100M downloads/month, affecting companies such as Amazon AWS

- **Package hijacked and poisoned w/ cryptominers and password-stealing malware** – Deliberate malware introduced into multiple packages with 30M downloads/month each

- **Package hijacked to add backdoor targeting a specific organization** – Obfuscated malware added to a dependency which targeted a single company, went undetected for over a week, and made it into their production build

- **NPM package manager allowed anyone to publish new versions of any package** – Attackers could publish new versions of any NPM package without authorization _for multiple years_

Using third-party dependencies without proper vetting leaves you open to hacking, breaches, and assorted security misfortune.

Why not leave it to the compiler? The access almost definitely will be optimized away.

My suggestion would be to evaluate the code in question and the context in which it will be executed to determine whether or not the proposed optimization would be beneficial.

If the loop runs many times or in an environment where gas is limited, such as in an Ethereum smart contract, optimization can be beneficial and save gas, especially if the array length is large.

On the other hand, if the loop is only executed a few times and gas is not a significant issue, optimization may not be necessary and may even degrade code readability.

578.body: Tick is a 24-bit value which I believe is being maintained for twat observations. While `SqrtPriceX96` contains more precision and is used for swap calculations, and based on it the tick is calculated and stored in the observation slots.

I found similar issue in transaction https://etherscan.io/tx/0x8bd6db6ee086f571da01b65101ca3368086f6184a662693e1c57d671b40bfbd6#eventlog

Price is supposedly in 203999 tick, when after calculating it, it goes into tick 204000. 

What's interesting, this kind of discrepancy is relatively new. I've checked thousands of swaps and never encountered one before ~ August 2022.

Hey @philipSKYBIT - thanks for reporting this! This is a known precision loss from `modifyPosition`, you can see some more details in this issue: https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/issues/424. 

> Please transfer the remaining 1 wei of token to my address ASAP so that I can proceed with what I need to do.

We won't be able to do this, as the pool contract is permissionless and doesn't have a dust withdrawal function. I'd suggest that folks running into this simply handle the slight precision loss in their integrations. 

The issue I linked above also has a few potential solutions listed, though since v3 is already deployed on mainnet and is immutable we likely won't be able to make those changes. For the time being, adding a note of this to the documentation might be helpful - feel free to submit a PR doing this if you're inclined.

565.body:
> PAXG is a fee-on-transfer token. Maybe this is the problem?

Yep, there would be an issue when someone is selling PAXG to the pool or adding liquidity in a range where PAXG amount is not zero, because Uniswap's contract checks for the increase in its balance, and it'd be less, hence these [checks](https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/blob/8f3e4645a08850d2335ead3d1a8d0c64fa44f222/contracts/UniswapV3Pool.sol#L483-L484) would fail.

You can still create a Wrapped PAXG ERC20 contract (similar to WETH), so it won't have fees on transfer. Also transferring/swapping WPAXG won't cost their fee-on-transfer as well, though it'd when unwrapping back to PAXG.

Hi @vovapwn - thanks for submitting this! Your intuition was correct; UniswapV3 doesn't support Fee-on-Transfer tokens, as outlined in the docs here https://docs.uniswap.org/protocol/concepts/advanced/integration-issues#fee-on-transfer-tokens.

As a late note to this discussion, you can now trade [PAXG on Uniwap v3 on Polygon](https://tradingstrategy.ai/trading-view/polygon/uniswap-v3/paxg-usdc-fee-30). This is because bridged or wrapped tokens do not inherit any transfer fee features of their underlying represented token.

Basically whatever `sqrtPriceLimitX96` you pass, if the price moves beyond that during the swap, it stops there, so it's sort of partial swap. While the SPL require statement just checks if sqrtPriceLimitX96 makes sense. If you want to not have partial swaps, you can simply look at `amountSpecified` and the return values of swap function and revert when partial swap (it should be equal to one of them based on swap dir and exactIn, if it's not eq then the swap was partial).

The SwapRouter contract allows to specify a min output amount (or max in), you can use that to ensure your swap was not partial ([link](https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-periphery/blob/main/contracts/SwapRouter.sol#L128)).

523.body:
Possible reasons I think:
- It doesn't use Minimal Proxy for deploying UniswapV3Pool in the protocol itself because swaps would cost an additional DELEGATECALL cost in swaps and operations. If deployment of a pool consumes 4,557,548 gas ([tx](https://etherscan.io/tx/0xdeb368592f3de0f2840754bce61d2c3f29cdb3407c63c699052e68a854c71eaa)), and cost for extra delegate call is 700 then after 4,557,548/700 = 6511 swaps, overall the protocol would be more costly. Hence the costly deployment of the contract makes sense (assuming the pool would be useful enough to cross at least 6511 number of transactions on it).
- NoDelegateCall might be used to prevent easy Uniswap forks.

If we use minimal proxy and calculate the fee at the gas price of 100 gwei, we will get this data: 

The fee will be rise on 0.00001 ETH (~0.03 USD) (DELEGATECALL costs 100 GAS) for the user. But the fee for deployment will drop from ~0.456 ETH (~1409 USD) to ~0.05 ETH (~154.5 USD).

one thing to consider is having additional libraries under `libraries/0_8_x` that are as well tested as the other core libraries

Experimentally it looks like
- `tickLow = calculated_log - 0.01`,
- `tickHi = calculated_log + (accuracy_limit + 0.01) = calculated_log + (2^-14 / log2(√1.0001) + 0.01) = calculated_log + 0.856`. We refined log2 upto 14 binary decimal places, implying that accuracy limit is 2^-14

 An [older commit](https://github.com/Uniswap/v3-core/commit/fccd58f42e6d2af6fa1bda342742b18ec8c0bbd5#diff-1f4e4c1696e7425edc3bd07a992bb1e23d735698d74dc0baf1c7331ba749fa72R134) using 7 digit refinement and `P = 0.01^t` in place of `√P = 0.0001^t` satisfies this condition, i.e. 188609930776236967625146103726555653720 / 2^128 = 0.5542 = 2^-7 / log2(1.01) + 0.01`.

Is this reasoning valid?
Perhaps this will help from Mikhail at ABDK: https://hackmd.io/@abdk/SkVJeHK9v

Implementation of tick calculation based on sqrt ratio seems to be well optimized. However I wonder if this additional optimization makes sense and can reduce gas consumption.

It seems that computing the exact tick is not needed. Instead, a tick aligned for a tick spacing is sufficient. This fact allows the logarithm to be computed with less accuracy. In consequence, less than `14 iterations` are needed to determine tick with at most one call to `getRatioAtTick`. Naturally, in the worst-case scenario (when tick `spacing = 1`), `14 iterations` must be performed, but in most cases the pool has tick spacing greater than `1 tick spacing`.

> It seems that computing the exact tick is not needed.

Computing the exact tick is needed, the result has to line up with getSqrtRatioAtTick

> > It seems that computing the exact tick is not needed.
> 
> Computing the exact tick is needed, the result has to line up with getSqrtRatioAtTick

The result has to line up with `getSqrtRatioAtTick` means

if `getTickAtSqrtRatio(sqrtP) = tick` then `getSqrtRatioAtTick(tick) = sqrtP`?

But there can be cases where sqrtP doesn't sit on a tick and `getSqrtRatioAtTick(tick) < sqrtP < getSqrtRatioAtTick(tick+1)`?

new description:

this PR introduces new behavior when a position is burning liquidity. specifically, if a position burns liquidity in the same block in which it minted liquidity, it forgoes any fees earned after the mint, for the whole block. this is intended to disincentivize fee siphoning sandwich attacks within a single block.

this can be (minimally) griefed as follows: every time a griefer sees your burn in the mempool, they can mint 1 wei to your position, forcing you to forgo fees earned _after_ that mint in the block. in the worst case, this simply acts as if you withdrew liquidity in that before any fees were generated.

note: sandwichers can still add liquidity, earn fees on it, and remove 1 block later, but this pr forces them to keep their liquidity in for at least a block if they want the fees.

from chat, this new implementation can be circumvented via

>  you mint x, the user trades, you mint 1 wei, then u burn x+1

226.body:
Cons:
1) removes the schelling point of fees = on, making it much harder to argue for any fee other than very close to 0
2) puts pressure on governance to set and adjust the fee for every pair, a responsibility it may not want (control is liability)
3) differences between protocol fees for different tokens may become points of friction

Pros:

1. More flexible / different protocol fees generally make sense for different pairs
2. Allows protocol to take more fees on pairs where LPs are super profitable while reducing fees on pairs where LPs are less profitable / taking on losses
3. Could maybe set a higher max fee since there is an expectation fees could be lower
4. Governance already turns fees on/off per pair so this is not that big of a change to the scope of governance
5. Someone/sushi could fork uniswap and reduce fees 50-75% and vampire attack. If gov has the option to lower it reduces the probability of this happening.
6. Gov could always use a wrapper to permanently lock in fees at 1/6th LP fees in the future

We generally agreed this would be good to do, with the implementation considerations below to be discussed in the implementation PR:

- min/max protocol fee number
- potentially replace per pair feeTo with per pair protocol fee amount

203.body:
some napkin math

```
in v2, ~150k txs/24hrs * 365 days/year
https://info.uniswap.org/home
assuming
* 60% of swaps are first swaps in block
* 90% of swaps move the price 0.5 bips (cross a 1bips tick boundary)
* 5k gas overhead / first swap
147_825_000_000 gas per year
~150 billion gas
assuming 1 million gas per merkle update
this allows for 150_000 merkle oracle updates/year
q: how many times in a year does eth/usdc cross a 0.5% deviation threshold for 30 min twap/10 min twap/5 min twap?
q: how many times a year does usdc/dai cross a 0.5% deviation threshold for 30 min twap/10 min twap/5 min twap?
```

also, in comparison to this method, merkle proof based oracles can:
- use checkpointed block hashes to support any time range (or an eip can update how many block hashes can be accessed to a larger number)
- be updated only when the price is needed (e.g. price deviation threshold, or threshold that allows liquidiation of certain positions, or permissionless DCA execution)
- only be used for pairs that need it

there are some complications with enforcing a minimum amount of (gross) liquidity at each tick:

a) if we only enforce min liquidity on liquidity additions, a troll could add min liquidity then remove all but 1 wei

b) if we enforce min liquidity, it's possible to lock LP tokens: troll adds min liquidity, honest user A adds <min liquidity, honest user B adds any amount of liquidity, troll removes liquidity, B can now only remove liquidity up to the threshold, and if they do A can't remove at all

c) we could enforce a minimum granularity of deposits (i.e. liquidity % MIN_GRANULARITY == 0)

to me, options a) and c) are too bad to consider, option b) may be acceptable if we make min liquidity low enough, and if we also make it clear to LPs that it's always possible that up to min liquidity of their liquidity could be locked

imo it's hard to future-proof this in a way that is particularly elegant. the blacklist approach is decent but still relies on a beneficent `feeToSetter`, so imo if we add this capability we should just assume that and do away with the security theater.

that being said, it's a very non-trivial assumption, so is this a power we want to endow the `feeToSetter` with? i think there are strong arguments both ways

> we should just assume that and do away with the security theater.

i think it's more than security theatre if the blocklist covers all known current implementations of erc20 at launch, and an append-only blocklist means that governance only has to be benevolent for long enough to blocklist new methods to prevent an attack on `UniswapV3Factory#owner` that would drain a pair

My initial reaction is leaning against.  Unknown unknowns are a bit spooky. 

For example, a governance token projects might not want Uniswap to be the primary marketplace for their tokens if Uniswap governance can vote with its full stack.

> For example, a governance token projects might not want Uniswap to be the primary marketplace for their tokens if Uniswap governance can vote with its full stack.

They don't really have a choice though--e.g. Compound didn't ask Uniswap permission to implement voting in cUni

We discussed at least 4 approaches--the allowlist style procedures are pretty much covered by hard coding recover/delegate

## Remove recover altogether
Pros
  - Trust minimized, as with v2 and v1
  - Smallest attack surface
  - Cleanest separation of concerns

Cons
  - Tokens deposited by Uniswap LPs cannot be used for delegation
  - Airdrops cannot be recovered
  - Tokens transferred accidentally to a pair are burned

Con mitigations
  - Tokens can be wrapped to include other functionalities e.g. delegation (LPs opt in)

## Allow only recover (hard code)
Pros
  - Tokens transferred to a pair (e.g. airdrop/accident) can be recovered by factory owner

Cons
  - Owner has to decide when and how to use the power

Con mitigations
  - ???

## Allow only recover and delegate (hard code)
Pros
  - Same as recover only
  - Owner can vote on behalf of liquidity providers

Cons
  - Owner has to decide when and how to use the power
  - LPs may be discouraged from providing liquidity that UNI uses to vote

Con mitigations
  - ??? wrapped tokens to *opt out*

## Generalize (any non-blocklisted address/data)
Pros
  - Owner has power to execute any function from a pair

Cons
  - Owner has to decide when and how to use the power
  - Potential for future unexpected attacks (increased attack surface)

Con mitigations
  - allowlist/blocklist (see above)

Here are my arguments against each idea. Ultimately I would probably be comfortable with transfer and/or delegate but not with generalized.

# Argument against allowing any of the possibilities

More complexity in the core contracts.

More pressure on governance to take actions that are possible, leading to infighting (like what happened when people proposed additional retroactive distributions) and fatigue that could weaken governance’s ability to perform its key functions. See Control as Liability: https://vitalik.ca/general/2019/05/09/control_as_liability.html

# transfer()

More pressure on governance to recover any tokens accidentally sent into contracts, or airdrops received by contracts. (However, this is something that could conceivably be streamlined more easily and in a more objective way than delegation or other functions.)

# delegate()

Some concern about security.

Pressures UNI governance to make political decisions about other protocols. Think about the minor fight about whether Maker should retaliate against Uniswap for considering subsidizing DAI liquidity less than USDT, but many times worse.

Could lead other protocols to discourage putting liquidity on Uniswap (or could directly discourage large holders from putting liquidity on Uniswap) for fear of giving UNI governance too much power over their protocols. 

# Generalized

Doesn’t support any other currently known use case other than transfer and delegation.

Significant concern about security—quite possible that many tokens have or will have an approve-like method that would give UNI governance the power to steal from the pair.

Changes the answer to “can UNI governance freeze or steal tokens from a Uniswap pair” from an essentially unqualified “no” to “usually not, but it depends on the token.” This is massive excess cognitive overhead that muddles the message when arguing about Uniswap’s security. Even with an allowlist and a timelock on governance, it requires going beyond the Uniswap core contracts and digging into governance’s current state to verify for oneself whether tokens are safe from governance attacks. See [this Twitter discussion that Hayden had](https://twitter.com/jaesf/status/1343350839373680641?s=21).

14.body:
After some discussion, I tentatively think the best approach is to simply charge this fee on the amount sent in, rather than trying to mint it as liquidity pool shares as v2 does. Unfortunately, this will mean that fees collected will not automatically contribute to the liquidity of the pool, but we think this approach is likely the simplest to implement and cheapest to execute (adding 1 CALL, 2 SLOADs, and 1 SSTORE).

This tentative spec assumes that `lpFee` is in units of 1/100 of a basis point, or 0.0001%.

- track `token0fees` and `token1fees` as state in the contract, initialized to 0
- in each `swap` function, before anything else happens, the contract checks if `feeTo` is set. If it is, the function does the following:
  - compute the `protocolFee` as `lpFee / 6` 
  - set `adjustedLpFee` to `lpFee * 5 / 6`
  - compute `amountToProtocol` as `amountIn * protocolFee / 1000000`
  - subtract `amountToProtocol` from `amountIn`
  - add `amountToProtocol` to `token0fees` or `token1fees`
- add a `withdrawFees(uint256 amount0Out, uint256 amount1Out)` function that can be called by `feeTo`, which allows the `feeTo` address to withdraw the specific amount of token0 and token1 (reducing the `token0fees` and `token1fees` balances)

On second thought, minting the fee on every tick cross seems likely to be cheaper (and simpler) than doing it on every trade. Not only do we expect the average trade to cross fewer than one tick, but we could actually batch all the SSTOREs when it crosses multiple ticks.

Unfortunately it does seem to require two SSTORES: one to the fee account's balance, and one to kLast. We could perhaps take the sqrt of kLast instead (making it a uint112) and cram it in next to virtualSupply, which needs to get updated on every tick-crossing trade anyway; I think this may still get us close to enough precision.
Minting the fee on every tick cross is implemented on `master`.

13.body:
* Denomination: in order to support the 1/6 protocol fee, as described in #14, we should probably use a smaller denomination than 1 bp, since otherwise rounding errors would have a significant effect on the size of the protocol fee compared to the size of the LP fee. I suggest 1/100th of a bp, although we may want to go even smaller.
* Bounds: I think 30 bps should be right in the middle of the range, so that if half of liquidity providers "push up" by voting the maximum and half of liquidity providers "push down" by voting the minimum, it lands on 30 bps. I think 0 bps as a lower bound is as good a choice as any, which means 60 bps would be the maximum.
* Default fee: while I like 30 bps as a default, I think we can simply require that every liquidity provider specify a vote for the fee. Our front-end could default to 30 bps if we decided that makes sense.
Won't there be pairs for which a fee higher than 60 bps is appropriate? Is there any pre existing work we can point to wrt the game theory?

> Won't there be pairs for which a fee higher than 60 bps is appropriate?

I kinda doubt it. I think there are a lot of Uniswap pairs where the fee is clearly too high (stablecoin pairs being the most obvious example) but I don't know if there's a pool I'd point to saying the fees are much too low.

I also think the possibility of pools having >60bp fees adds a little cognitive overhead to the system.

> Is there any pre existing work we can point to wrt the game theory?

Not sure. And I'm not sure there is guaranteed to be an equilibrium. But maybe we just have to tolerate that.

3.body:
Agnostic on whether we should try one-way leverage, but here’s a draft spec of how it could work:

- `struct ExitingLiquidity({ quantity: uint256, invariant: uint256 })`
  - invariant is 0 until the cycle has passed, at which point it is set to x*y/shares^2 (the fee accumulation invariant)
- `mapping (uint256 => mapping (uint256 => ExitingLiquidity)) liquidityExits` mapping from `(tick, cycle)` to an ExitingLiquidity struct.
- The struct for a tick (which tracks the amount of leverage that is temporarily added or removed when the tick is crossed) tracks its cycle (which should always be even when the price is below the tick and odd when the price is above the tick).
- When a tick is crossed, the cycle is incremented, the appropriate ExitingLiquidity struct is read. The liquidityDelta number (the amount of liquidity that is pushed in or out when the tick is crossed) is decremented by `quantity`. The ExistingLiquidity struct is updated with the token0value and token1value (this update can be skipped if `quantity` is 0).
- When someone sets their bounds, they can configure it to be a permanent exit by setting some parameter, which increments the `quantity` in the appropriate ExitingLiquidity struct by their quantity of liquidity, and stores the current `cycle` for that tick in the user’s struct.
- When someone who has set such a bound exits and that `cycle` has passed, their balances are computed as if they had exited at the time that cycle was passed (with the help of the stored `x*y/shares^2` value)
On further consideration, I now don't think Uniswap core needs to support limit orders at all, which makes this question moot.
Closing, since for now we're moving forward with no limit orders.
